channel.title: One Square Meter
channel.description: A year-long biodiversity documetation of 1m² area in Gundmi, India.

item.title: Sighting: Braconid Wasp
item.description:
Braconid Wasp (Braconidae sp)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

About 3mm long, it sat still, but I couldn't get a neat picture because of my skill issues.

Weather: 28.2°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Golden-backed Ant
item.description:
Golden-backed Ant (Polyrhachis sp)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Such a neat ant! It has golden butt!

Weather: 28.2°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Chalcid Wasp
item.description:
Chalcid Wasp (Sycophila sp)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

It has some patterns on its back, should try to get a clear pic next time.

Weather: 28.2°C, Overcast

item.title: Week 2: Ants marching
item.description:
I have started talking to bugs.

Hello!

Did you know that ants do not trigger the touch-me-not plant’s defense mechanism? So cool!

Well, would you look at that stats page, so many numbers! I think I have documented quite a lot of “resident” bugs, and now the number of new species I encounter might start to decrease.

If you are planning to start a similar project, make sure you do not pick a plot right below a coconut tree. The plot I selected, however, is right beneath one. The tree’s branches look like they are ready fall at any moment. So, this bug documentation project has turned into an adventure sport!

Note to self: Be graceful in your movements. Do not spook the bugs.

’Til next week!

item.title: Sighting: Maize Leafhopper
item.description:
Maize Leafhopper (Cicadulina mbila)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Looks like a leafhopper alright!

Weather: 28.9°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Common Drone Fly
item.description:
Common Drone Fly (Eristalis tenax)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

It just wouldn't sit on the flower. Just kept moving up and down, nonstop.

Weather: 28.9°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Snout Beetle
item.description:
Snout Beetle (Curculionidae sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Just wouldn't step in to the sun, kept hiding under the leaves. Took a lot of moving around to take a pic.

Weather: 28.9°C, Overcast

item.description:

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Is it an ant? Is it a beetle? Oh man.

Weather: 28.9°C, Overcast

Just a fly.

Weather: 28.9°C, Overcast

Weather: 28.9°C, Overcast

Weaver Ant (Oecophylla smaragdina)

item.description:

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

I was wondering when will a mosquito appear. Here it is.

Weather: 27.9°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Stilt-legged Fly
item.description:
Stilt-legged Fly (Micropezidae Sp)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

It can not stand still! Keeps moving its hands every second!

Weather: 27.8°C, Mainly clear

item.title: Sighting: Indian Black Ant
item.description:
Indian Black Ant (Polyrhachis tibialis)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Good looking ant! It stood still for a while, allowing me some good photos.

Weather: 27.8°C, Mainly clear

item.description:
Mung Moth (Maruca vitrata)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

They are always upside down for some reason.

Weather: 27.8°C, Mainly clear

item.title: Sighting: Ghost Ants
item.description:
Ghost Ants (Tapinoma melanocephalum)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

These are small, but can you give you a neat bite.

Weather: 27.8°C, Mainly clear

item.title: Sighting: Indian Stingless Bee
item.description:
Indian Stingless Bee (Tetragonula iridipennis)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

This one just collected as much pollen as possible! Tiny though, perhaps 3-4 mm in length.

Weather: 29.1°C, Overcast

Carpet Beetle (Anthrenus verbasci)

This one has fuzzy texture. For a while I thought picture is getting out of focus. Nope!

item.title: Sighting: Grass Moth
item.description:
Grass Moth (Crambidae sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

I am so not sure what species, family, order, etc etc.

Weather: 28.5°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Week 1: Not bad!
item.description:
My knees hurt.

Hello!

So, end of the week (well, just 4 days)! 20 species found, from very tiny to slightly bigger ones!

I saw 3 new hoppers that I hadn't seen before. They are tiny!

So, the morning light is not enough to get good quality photos, I have to bump up ISO, which leads to very grainy images. Looks like I will spend monies on a flash. Sigh.

My macro photography skills have rusted. I am hoping it will get better as the time goes on.

I also discoverd a very similar project done before by Chris Helzer. Read about it here. The photographs he has taken are very clean and precise! Now I have a benchmark to aim for!

One week at a time!

item.title: Day one!
item.description:
So it begins.

Hello world!

Welcome to a square meter project, here we like bugs. Find more about the project in the about section.

Today, I set up the fence posts on 4 corners of the patch, cleaned up the space a bit, placed an old wood piece in it. That is it. No more fiddling with the patch for the rest of the year.

My first immediate dilemma is this:

If I spot a bug within the square meter but it moves out of the boundary before I can get a photo, should I still take the picture and count it as a sighting, or should I let it go?
